message_1: Let X be a smooth algebraic variety defined over the field of complex numbers. Assume that X is birational to a smooth projective variety. If X has a minimal model, then its Picard number is less than or equal to what number?
message_2:
The Picard number of a smooth algebraic variety X, denoted as ρ(X), is the rank of the Picard group Pic(X), which is the group of isomorphism classes of line bundles on X. The Picard number is an important invariant in algebraic geometry, as it measures the complexity of the variety.

If X has a minimal model, then it is a variety with the smallest possible Picard number among all varieties that are birational to X. In this case, the minimal model program (MMP) provides a way to study the birational geometry of X by analyzing its minimal model.

The Picard number of a minimal model is bounded by the dimension of the Néron-Severi group of the variety, which is a lattice generated by the classes of divisors on the variety. The Néron-Severi group is a finitely generated abelian group, and its rank is called the Néron-Severi rank.

In general, it is difficult to give an explicit upper bound for the Picard number of a minimal model, as it depends on the specific properties of the variety and its birational class. However, it is known that the Picard number is always a non-negative integer, and it is less than or equal to the Néron-Severi rank of the variety.

In summary, the Picard number of a minimal model of a smooth algebraic variety X defined over the field of complex numbers and birational to a smooth projective variety is less than or equal to the Néron-Severi rank of the variety. However, without more information about the specific variety, it is not possible to give a more precise upper bound.
